historicalDescription: A residential street in the Cannaregio sestiere, near the northern edge of Venice. The area was known for its proximity to the Jewish Ghetto, which was established in 1516.

canalPoints.historicalDescription: Named after the prominent Loredan family who owned palaces in this area of Cannaregio. The Loredan family produced several doges of Venice, including Leonardo Loredan (1501-1521), who ruled during the War of the League of Cambrai.

Cannaregio was home to many textile workshops, including silk merchants. This dock would have served as a loading point for valuable silk products, which were a crucial part of Venice's luxury trade with the East during the Renaissance.

canalPoints.englishName: Foundation of the Madonna of Miracles
canalPoints.historicalDescription: Named for its proximity to the Church of Santa Maria dei Miracoli, one of Venice's most elegant Renaissance churches. This dock would have served pilgrims and worshippers coming to visit this important religious site in the nearby area.

Located near Venice's Jewish Ghetto, established in 1516 in Cannaregio. This dock would have been an important access point for Jewish merchants and residents, as the ghetto was surrounded by canals and access was strictly controlled.
Named after the nearby Monastery of Reformed Franciscans that existed in Cannaregio during the Renaissance. The dock would have served the monastery for supplies and transportation of clergy members.

Named for the Lombard merchants and bankers who established businesses in this area of Cannaregio. Immigrants from Lombardy formed a significant foreign community in Renaissance Venice, contributing to its commercial prosperity.

Named for the noble women who resided in the elegant palaces along this waterway. In Renaissance Venice, nobili families often had their palaces built with water gates, and this dock would have served the female members of these households.

Wine was a significant import to Venice, especially from mainland territories and Greece. This dock in Cannaregio would have specialized in the unloading and storage of wine barrels, serving the numerous taverns and households in the area.

connection.historicalDescription: Named after the prestigious Loredan family who owned property in this area of Cannaregio. The Loredans were an ancient Venetian nobili family that provided several Doges to the Republic, including Leonardo Loredan (1501-1521), who governed during the War of the League of Cambrai.

This bridge likely earned its name due to its proximity to palaces where foreign ambassadors might have resided or passed through when traveling to and from the Ducal Palace. Cannaregio, being one of the access points to the city from the mainland, was often traversed by diplomatic missions.

Named for the silk workers who operated in this area of Cannaregio during the Renaissance. Venice was famous for its silk industry, having learned the craft from Byzantine and Oriental traditions, and this bridge would have connected workshops or warehouses related to this prestigious guild.

buildingPoints.streetDescription: This street was named after Byzantine merchants who had established trading posts in Cannaregio during the early Renaissance. The Loredan family, who resided nearby, had significant commercial ties with Constantinople, making this naming historically relevant to the area.

This former canal was filled in and named after the silk trade that flourished in this part of Cannaregio. Many silk weavers established workshops near the Loredan family properties, as the family were patrons of luxury textile arts in the 15th century.

Named after the night watchmen who patrolled this area of Cannaregio, ensuring security for the wealthy families like the Loredans. The watch station was established in the early 16th century as part of Venice's sophisticated urban security system.

This waterfront street was named after a charitable institution founded in the late 15th century with contributions from the Loredan family. The confraternity provided assistance to the poor and sick residents of Cannaregio.

This covered passageway was named after the paper makers who had workshops nearby. The production of high-quality paper was crucial for Venice's publishing industry, and several paper artisans operated in this part of Cannaregio during the Renaissance.

This commercial street housed several clockmaking workshops in the 16th century. The Loredan family, known for their patronage of mechanical arts, helped establish this specialized trade in their neighborhood of Cannaregio.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Paved Street of the Little Greeks
buildingPoints.streetDescription: One of the few paved streets in Renaissance Venice, named after the small community of Greek Orthodox families who settled in this part of Cannaregio. They maintained close diplomatic relationships with noble families, including the Loredans.

Named after the parchment makers who supplied materials for Venetian documents and manuscripts. Their workshops were established near the Loredan residences in Cannaregio, as the family had several members who served as diplomats and required quality writing materials.

This small courtyard was named after Leonardo Loredan, who became Doge of Venice in 1501. The ducal hat (corno ducale) symbolized his position, and this court was close to one of the Loredan family properties in Cannaregio.

This small square was named after the specialized blacksmiths who produced metal components for Venetian ships. The naval blacksmiths established workshops in Cannaregio due to its proximity to the Arsenal, and were supported by the influential Loredan family.

This former canal was filled in and named to commemorate the many foreign ambassadors who visited the Loredan palaces in Cannaregio. The Loredan family produced several diplomats who served the Republic of Venice in the 15th and 16th centuries.

Named after the booksellers who established shops in this area following the development of printing in Venice in the late 15th century. The Loredan family were known patrons of literature and collected an impressive library in their Cannaregio residence.

This passageway was named after a heraldic symbol associated with the Loredan family. The golden lion appeared in variations of their coat of arms, and this underpass connected two properties owned by different branches of the family in Cannaregio.

This waterfront street was named after the professional oarsmen who served on Venetian galleys. Many retired oarsmen settled in this part of Cannaregio, and some worked for the Loredan family as gondoliers or boat operators for their commercial ventures.

Named after the famous Aldine Press, which revolutionized printing in Renaissance Venice. Aldus Manutius established connections with noble families including the Loredans, and this street in Cannaregio commemorates the spread of humanist literature that the press facilitated.

This small side street was named after specialty shops selling exotic spices from the East. The Loredan family invested heavily in the spice trade with the Orient, and this branch street in Cannaregio contained several shops selling their imported goods during the Renaissance period.
